H0.text: Bryophyta are the plant group to which ferns belong, encompassing about 12,000 species of vascular, seedless, flowerless plants that reproduce by spores.

H1.text: Gymnosperm are ferns that belong to about 12,000 species of vascular, seedless, flowerless plants that reproduce by spores and are grouped in their own division within the plant kingdom.

H2.text: Angiosperm is the plant group to which ferns belong, a vascular, seedless, flowerless group that reproduces by spores and contains about 12,000 species in its own division within the plant kingdom.

H3.text: Pteridophyta are the plant group to which ferns—about 12,000 species of vascular, seedless, flowerless plants that reproduce by spores and belong to their own division within the plant kingdom—belong.

A4.text: Ferns differ from non-vascular plants (moss Highland, hornworts and liverworts) by having specialized transport bundles that conduct water and nutrients from and to the roots.

A5.text: Pteridophyta is no longer recognised as a valid taxon because it is paraphyletic.

A6.text: Pteridophyta is no longer a widely accepted taxon because it is paraphyletic.

A7.text: Ferns are vascular plants, whereas Bryophyta are non-vascular.
